def: Someone willing to take the risks involved in starting a new business
Raw materials that have not yet been used or products that have been made but not sold. There are also called stocks.
Money that is available from within the business. EG retained profits.
Money put into the business by its owners
A payment made in order to borrow money. It means a business pays back more than it borrows.
A person or organisation that owns part of a company.
Something that is owned by a business. EG Machinery or buildings
A period of time which suppliers allow customers before payment for supplies must be made.
Refers to money that comes from outside the business. EG A loan from a bank.
An asset that a bank holds as security for the repayment of a loan
Loads from banks and build societies that are used to buy land and buildings.
Organisations that offer a range of financial services. Mostly they provide savings accounts and mortgages.
A flexible loan which businesses can use up to a agreed limit
The money that flows into and out of a business on a day-to-day basis
A plan of the expected inflows and outflows to and from a business over a period of time
A record of the cash inflows and outflows tat took place over an earlier period of time
Measures the difference between the values of a business revenue and its total costs
The income that a firm receives from selling its goods or servicces. It is also referred to as turnover.
The number of products sold by a business
The spending that is necessary to set up and run a business
Costs that do not hange when a business changes its output
Costs that vary directly with the business level of output
This is the total of fixed costs plus variable costs
Measures the difference between the values of a business revenue and its total costs
The amount by which a business costs are larger than its revenue
This takes place when a business buys an asset. EG A factory or training for staff.
This compares the average yearly profit from an investment with the cost of the investment and is stated as a percentage
The level of production at which a businesses total costs and revenue from sales are equal
This shows a business cost and revenues and the level of product needed to break even.
Measures the amount by which the current level of production exceeds its break-even level of output.
A financial statement showing a businesses revenues and costs.
This sets out the assets and liabilities that a business has on a particular day
The sales revenue inus its costs of sales over a period of time - normally a year
This is the sales revenue of a business minus all costs over a period of time - normally a year
A sum of money that is owed by a business to another business or individual
This compares two figures from the businesses financial statements.
Individuals and organisations that are affected by and affect the business
